Sources: art. 150.1 of the Constitution, In addition to art. 150.1 Cst., art. 150.3 Cst. foresees a special law on principles and procedures for Referenda. Art. 185 Electoral Code mentions that a new law on general and local referenda should be introduced. So far, no such law has been adopted or proposed. Art. 185 Electoral Code mentions that a new law on general and local referenda should be introduced. So far, no such law has been adopted or proposed. In accordance with art. 185.2 of the Electoral Code, the old Electoral Code, part 9, articles 118 ff. apply.

Sources: The electoral Code foresees detailed deadlines for the Central Electoral Commission (articles 127 and 128) and for the Constitutional Court (art. 129) to handle a request for referendum. Nothing is said with respect to the duration of signature collection.
Comment: The old electoral Code foresees detailed deadlines for the Central Electoral Commission (articles 127 and 128) and for the Constitutional Court (art. 129) to handle a request for referendum. Nothing is said with respect to the duration of signature collection.

Articles 120.1; 127.2 and in particular 128.1 old Electoral Code.

Question: Who checks the signatures?
Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Is there a formal admissibility check?
Who decides about the formal admissibility?
Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Comment: The initiants have the possibility to declare within 5 days its agreement to correct the irregularities identified by the CEC and to do the correction within maximum 30 days (exact deadline to be determined by CEC).

Question: Who decides about the claim for remedy in the formal admissibility procedure?
Who can initiate the formal remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Does the formal admissibility procedure take place before the signature collection?
Comment: One can deduce by reading 126.5 and 127 of the old Electoral Code that there is a formal admissibility procedure before the CEC prints the forms for gathering signatures, to check that the question is well formulated. However the Code only mentions the verification procedure in art. 128 which refers to the control after collection of signatures. The sublegal acts and the law on referendums have not been introduce so far, so it is not clear what kind of control the CEC should conduct before signature collection.

Question: Is formal admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Do participants have a right to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure?
Sources: art. 128.3 Electoral Code, Right to be heard limited to "accept to correct the irregularities". They cannot argue to defend their decision. As mentioned, a specific law on referenda and detailed regulations have not yet been introduced.

Question: Is there an evidentiary procedure in the formal admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Is invalidity the legal consequence of formal inadmissibility?
Comment: Invalidity is not mentioned as such but is the de facto consequence of inadmissibility.

Question: Is there an evidentiary procedure in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the substantive admissibility procedure binding?
Sources: Articles 131.1.ë; 152 (esp. point 2) Cst. and art. 129.3 old Electoral Code
Comment: They are binding if the admissibility is not given (i.e. the constitutionality test fails). If the constitutionality test passes, there is still the question of "particular importance" to be decided. This is outside the scope of adjudication of the Constitutional Court (art. 152.2 Cst.). The President has to take the decision.

Question: Is invalidity the legal consequence of substantive inadmissibility?
Does the proposal have to be submitted as a (draft) legal text?
Comment: However it has to be formulated clearly, in a complete and unequivocal manner in order for the voter to be able to reply simply by yes or no.

Question: Are there any formal limits on the wording of the referendum proposal?
Is there a clarity of the question requirement?
Comment: The issue must be stated in a clear, complete, and unequivocal manner, and expressed in such a form that voters can answer "Yes" or "No."

Question: Is the instrument available at national level?

Comment: at least 10% of the citizens who have the right to vote (in the general elections)

Question: Is there a territorial threshold for signature gathering?
What is the time limit for collecting the required number of signatures (in days)?
Comment: There is no regulation that precisely determines the procedure that must be followed to carry out a proposal of law derived from a popular legislative initiative.

Question: Are there any restrictions on where the signatures can be collected?
Comment: There is no regulation that precisely determines the procedure that must be followed to carry out a proposal of law derived from a popular legislative initiative.

Question: Do signatories have to provide identification documents in addition to personal information when signing the initiative?
Comment: They do not have to but signatures have to be checked by the Speaker's Office

Question: Is it possible to gather signatures electronically?
Comment: They are being collected in paper version.

Question: Are the signatures systematically verified?
Who checks the signatures?
Sources: art. 103 par. 1 of the Regulations of the General Council
Comment: The relevant article states that private bills (so popular initiatives as well), with the corresponding explanatory notes, are presented in writing to the Sindicatura (Speaker's Office), together with a supporting report and, whenever possible, a financial report and a report proving that the legislative initiative has adequately considered the gender perspective, and any necessary background to be able to formulate an opinion.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Comment: There is no regulation that precisely determines the procedure that must be followed to carry out a proposal of law derived from a popular legislative initiative. While the first (ever) initiative was launched in 2010 the initiators noticed the lack of proper procedures.

Comment:
While it has to be noted that the proposal cannot change the Constitution (so there is a special procedure of so-called "constitutional reform"). So there is no regulations enumerating issues which cannot be changed by the initiative, but there are regulations on changing the Constitution which exclude citizens from that procedure. 
The initiative on the bill for the General Budget Law is given to the Government (while the popular initiative probably could propose some changes within).

Are referendums on constitutional amendments prohibited?
Are referendums related to international law obligations prohibited?
Comment: Generally no, however Article 5 does prohibit referenda regarding international treaties. No other international law obligations are mentioned in the prohibited list.

Question: Are referendums related to fundamental rights and freedoms prohibited?
Comment: Article 5 prohibits referenda on Articles 1-3 of the Constitution, with Article 3 being "The Human Being, His or Her Dignity, Basic Rights and Freedoms" However, basic rights, e.g. right to equality, are spelled out in articles that can be the subject of a referendum.

Question: Are referendums on state structure or form of government prohibited?
Are referendums on state symbols prohibited?
Are referendums on the official language prohibited?
Are referendums on territorial issues or territorial integrity prohibited?
Comment: Yes regarding administrative-territorial division, no regarding territorial integrity

Question: Are referendums on state finances (budget, taxes, or other financial obligations) prohibited?

Comment: Generally no, but there is a prohibition on the creation of inter-community unions (Art. 5(2) Law on Referenda). Community in this cases refers to a community within the State of Armenia, not to international affairs.

Comment: 100000 or it is also possible to initiate by one sixth of the constituents of 3 Bundesländer

Comment: Most of the signatures are given in person at a local authority, the online signatures are checked by the Ministry of Interior.

Comment: It's not explicitly forbidden by the Constitution, but it is a common opinion in literature that no referendum can be held on bugdetary issues: Storr (2010) Die Maßgaben der österreichischen Bundesverfassung für sachunmittelbare Demokratie in Bund und Ländern, in: Neumann, Peter/ Renger, Denise (Hrsg.): Sachunmittelbare Demokratie im interdisziplinären und internationalen Kontext 2008/2009. Deutschland, Österreich, Schweiz, Baden-Baden 2010 (Studien zur Sachunmittelbaren Demokratie: Band 7).

Does any constitutional amendment trigger a referendum?
Do certain constitutional amendments trigger a referendum?
Comment: A referendum has to be called, if one of the 'Baugesetze' of the Constitution is changed. This is the case, when the very substance of the constitution (like the federal system) is in question. As this is a very rare situation, there was only one law-initiated referendum triggered by Art 44 (3) in history: when Austria joined the European Union.

Question: Does the total revision of the constitution trigger a referendum?
Sources: Article 44 (3) of the Constitution, Volksabstimmungsgesetz 1972 - VAbstG

Question: Do territorial changes trigger a referendum?
Comment: A territorial change may be considered such an essencial change to the Constitution that would trigger a referendum under Article 44 (3) of the Constitution.

Question: Does the ratification of any international treaty trigger a referendum?
Does the ratification of certain international treaties trigger a referendum?
Does the association with any other state or international organisation trigger a referendum?
Does the association with certain states or international organisations trigger a referendum?
Are there any other issues or events that trigger a referendum?
Comment: The impeachment of the Federal President triggers a referendum, however, it is a recall which is outside the scope of this research.

Question: Are there any exceptions when a referendum is not required to take place even though the triggering event or issue exists?
Are there any procedures for reviewing the triggering issue or event?
Comment: First, the 'Verfassungsdienst' in the Parliament and the Chancellery review whether Art 44 (3) has been triggered. If it's not clear, the Austrian Constitutional Court has to decide.

Regional level: Vorarlberg (LGBl.Nr. 60/1987), Burgenland: Anordnung einer Volksabstimmung (LGBl. Nr. 61/1987), Kärntner Volksabstimmungsgesetz - K-VabstG, NÖ Volksbegehrens-, Volksabstimmungs- und Volksbefragungsgesetz; Salzburger Volksabstimmungs- und Volksbegehrengesetz (LGBl. Question: Is the instrument available at national level?
Comment: An optional referendum can be initiated by the parliamentary minority (a third of any of the two chambers, Nationalrat or Bundesrat) only when it concerns a partial revision of the constitution. Partial revision means changing a 'Bundesverfassungsgesetz', i.e. a legal provision that has constitutional status as it was enacted according to  Art. 44 Abs. 1 B-VG, § 82 Abs. 2 Z 1 GOG-NR. In case of laws without constitutional status, the majority in the first chamber (Nationalrat) is needed to call for a referendum. The second chamber (Bundesrat) is not entitled to initiate. The legislature is also entitled to initiate a national consultation.

Question: Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
Under what conditions can the instrument be initiated (number of ministers, whole government, President etc.)?
Comment: Minority of deputies for the partial revision of the constitution (Art. 44 (3) of the Constitution). Majority of deputies for any enactment of the National Council (Art. 43) and for the consultation with the people on a matter of fundamental and overall national importance (Art. 49b)

Question: Is the instrument available at national level?
Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
What is the total number of signatures required?
Comment: Drafts of laws or decrees submitted for consideration by 40 thousand citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan enjoying suffrage as legislative initiative, are put to the vote as they are.

Question: Is there a territorial threshold for signature gathering?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 6 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Electoral districts are the territorial threshold for signature gathering

Question: What is the time limit for collecting the required number of signatures (in days)?
Sources: Part 1 of Article 6 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The collection of signatures of citizens to support the proposed project submitted for discussion by the Milli Majlis is carried out only by members of the initiative group within two months from the date of registration of the proposed project.

Question: Are there any restrictions on where the signatures can be collected?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 6 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The collection of signatures must cover at least the territory of 60 electoral districts and 500 signatures from the territory of each electoral district.

Question: Do signatories have to provide identification documents in addition to personal information when signing the initiative?
Sources: Part 3 of Article 6 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The signature list for collecting signatures must contain ..... the last name, first name, and patronymic of the citizen supporting the proposed project, address of residence, ID number, and its expiration date.

Question: Is it possible to gather signatures electronically?
Comment: The signatures are put in the list for collecting signatures and no electronic signature may be used.

Question: Are the signatures systematically verified?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Each folder with signature sheets is sealed and the compliance of the number of submitted signature sheets with the Protocol on the results of collecting signatures of citizens are checked.

Question: Who checks the signatures?
Sources: Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Central election Commission checks the signatures.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Sources: Parts 10 and 11 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: A copy of the decision of the Central election Commission on non-compliance of the initiative group with the requirements of this Law shall be submitted to the Chairman of the initiative group within 3 working days from the date of adoption of this decision. In the event of an insufficient number of signatures, the initiative group has the right not only to obtain a copy of the report, but a copy of the table of validation results showing the invalidity of the signature rooms in the appropriate folder, the line number in the corresponding subscription list. The decision of the Central election Commission on non-compliance of the initiative group with the requirements of this Law may be appealed to the court of appeal.

Question: Is there a formal admissibility check?
Sources: Articles 6 and 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan; Article 59 of the Election Code of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Question: Who decides about the formal admissibility?
Sources: Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Within two months, the Central Election Commission verifies the correctness of the information contained in the subscription lists, as well as compliance by the initiative group with the requirements of this Law in accordance with article 59 of the Electoral Code of the Republic of Azerbaijan.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Sources: Part 11 of the Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The decision of the Central Election Commission may be appealed to the court of appeal.

Question: Who decides about the claim for remedy in the formal admissibility procedure?
Sources: Part 11 of Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The claim may be brought before the Court of Appeal of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Question: Who can initiate the formal remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Sources: Part 11 of Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Initiative group may appeal the decision of the Commission

Question: Does the formal admissibility procedure take place before the signature collection?
Sources: Part 3 of Article 7 the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Within two months, the Central Election Commission verifies the correctness of the information contained in the subscription lists, as well as compliance by the initiative group with the requirements of this Law in accordance with article 59 of the Electoral code of the Republic of Azerbaijan.

Question: Is formal admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Sources: Part 5 of Article 7 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The head of the working group (a member of the Central election Commission with the right to vote) established in accordance with the Electoral code of the Republic of Azerbaijan shall draw up a Protocol, sign it and submit it to the Central election Commission for decision-making. The Protocol specifies the number of verified signatures of citizens, as well as the number of invalid signatures indicating the basis.

Question: Do participants have a right to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure?
Comment: The Law does not define any right of participants to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure

Question: Is there an evidentiary procedure in the formal admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Comment: The admissibility procedures result with the adoption of decision of Central Election Commission. The decision is binding if the Initiative Group does not bring appeal before the court.

Question: Is invalidity the legal consequence of formal inadmissibility?
Comment: It depends on the decision of the court

Question: Is there a substantive admissibility check?
Who decides about the substantive admissibility?
Is there a legal remedy against the decision on substantive admissibility?

Sources: Part 1 of Article 8 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Within one month from the date of adoption of the decision of the Central Election Commission on compliance of the initiative group with the requirements of this law, the project is submitted to the Milli Majlis by the initiative group.

Question: Are there any formal limits on the wording of the referendum proposal?
Sources: Part 1 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: A draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative must meet the requirements set out in Articles 50, 53-58 and 62.4 of the Constitutional Law of the Republic of Azerbaijan on Normative Legal Acts. Articles 53-58 of the Constitutional Law of the Republic of Azerbaijan on Normative Legal Acts defines the standards on mandatory linguistic expertise of the draft normative legal acts. Precisely, the text of the normative legal act is compiled in a laconic form, in a simple and clear language, excluding the contradictory interpretation of norms, following the official-working style of the Azerbaijani literary language and legal terminology. In the text of a normative legal act the following statements are not allowed: colloquy, dialects of the Azerbaijani language and expressive forms of colloquial speech; different concepts (terms) in the same sense; borrowing words from other languages if there are identical words and terms in the Azerbaijani language; incomprehensible phrases, generalized thoughts, appeals, artistic comparisons, epithets, metaphors; abbreviations (except known ones).

Question: Is there a clarity of the question requirement?
Sources: Articles 53-58 of the Constitutional Law of the Republic of Azerbaijan on Normative Legal Acts

Question: Is there a unity of form requirement?
Is there a unity of substance requirement?
Sources: Articles 53-58 of the Constitutional Law of the Republic of Azerbaijan on Normative Legal Acts

Question: Are there any other formal limits? If Yes, describe in comments.
Can only issues of special importance be the subject of referendums?
Can only certain enumerated issues be the subject of referendums?
Comment: Neither the Constitution, nor the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan defines certain list of issues that are the subjects of an agenda.

Question: Are there any prohibited issues?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative may not include the following issues: state budget, state duty, taxes and customs; the amount of salary and the procedure for its payment; criminal or administrative errors; family relations; the territorial device and administrative-territorial division; approval and termination of intergovernmental agreements that provide for rules other than the laws of the Republic of Azerbaijan; elections and referendums; Confidence in the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Azerbaijan; amnesty; election, appointment or approval of officials, the selection, appointment or approval of which is assigned to the powers of legislative and (or) executive authorities, respectively.

Question: Are referendums on constitutional amendments prohibited?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Part 2 of Article 3 alongwith other issues that are not included to the draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative defines the issues on referendum. As constitutional amendments are made only by way of referendum, these issues as agenda initiatives are prohibited.

Question: Are referendums related to international law obligations prohibited?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Approval and termination of intergovernmental agreements that provide for rules other than the laws of the Republic of Azerbaijan is included to the list of issues that are prohibited as draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative.

Question: Are referendums related to fundamental rights and freedoms prohibited?
Comment: Proposals about restriction or abolition of human and citizen's rights and freedoms set forth in Chapter III of the present Constitution are prohibited at all.

Question: Are referendums on state structure or form of government prohibited?
Comment: Proposals about changes or abolition in Articles 1, 2, 6, 7, 8 and 21, about restriction or abolition of human and citizen's rights and freedoms or to higher degree than it is specified in international treaties to which Azerbaijan Republic is a party are prohibited. Article 7 of the Constitution states that 'State power in the Azerbaijan Republic is based on a principle of separation of powers'. Consequently, agenda initiatives on state structure or form of government are prohibited.

Question: Are referendums on state symbols prohibited?
Are referendums on the official language prohibited?
Comment: Proposals about changes or abolition in Articles 1, 2, 6, 7, 8 and 21, about restriction or abolition of human and citizen's rights and freedoms or to higher degree than it is specified in international treaties to which Azerbaijan Republic is a party are prohibited. Article 21 of the Constitution sets up the rules concerning official language of the country. Consequently, agenda initiatives on the official language are prohibited.

Question: Are referendums on territorial issues or territorial integrity prohibited?
Comment: Change of the borders is included in the list of issues that are solved by referendum and agenda initiatives in this regard are prohibited.

Question: Are referendums on state finances (budget, taxes, or other financial obligations) prohibited?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: State budget, state duty, taxes and customs are included to the list of issues that are prohibited as draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative.

Question: Are referendums on issues related to national security (military, police, secret services) prohibited?
Are referendums on emergency powers (declaration of war, state of emergency etc) or urgent matters prohibited?
Are referendums on pardon and amnesty prohibited?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Amnesty is included to the list of issues that are prohibited as draft law submitted by citizens as a legislative initiative. Pardon is included in the list of exclusive competences of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan. Amnesty is included in the list of competences of the Milli Mejlis of the Republic of Azerbaijan.

Question: Are referendums on naturalisation issues prohibited?
Are referendums on minorities or minority rights prohibited?
Comment: Proposals about restriction or abolition of human and citizen's rights and freedoms set forth in Chapter III of the present Constitution are prohibited. Human and citizen's rights and freedoms set forth in Chapter III of the present Constitution also inherent to minorities who are citizens and/or non-citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan.

Question: Are referendums on the rules of elections and referendums prohibited?
Comment: Any proposal about restriction or abolition of human and citizen's rights and freedoms set forth in Chapter III of the present Constitution is prohibited. Human and citizen's rights and freedoms set forth in Chapter III of the present Constitution also inherent to minorities who are citizens and/or non-citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan.

Question: Are referendums on the election or appointment of state officials or civil service laws prohibited?
Sources: Part 2 of Article 3 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Sources: Part 2 of Article 8 of the Law on the procedure for using the rights of legislative initiative by citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: The draft is submitted to the Milli Majlis for discussion and put to a vote within two months.

Comment: According to Article 7 of the Constitution Azerbaijani state is ..... unitary republic. It means that no subnational election process may exist in the territory of Azerbaijan.

Sources: Articles 3 and 152 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: People of Azerbaijan may solve any questions involving their rights and interests by way of referendum. One of the questions that are solved only by way of referendum is the making amendments to the Constitution of the Azerbaijan Republic.

Question: Do certain constitutional amendments trigger a referendum?
Sources: Articles 3 and 152 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Question: Does the total revision of the constitution trigger a referendum?
Sources: Articles 3 and 152 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Article 3 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan, generally, defines the adoption of the Constitution of the Azerbaijan Republic which is made by the referendum. But there is no explicit situation on the total revision of the constitution

Question: Do territorial changes trigger a referendum?
Sources: Article 3 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan
Comment: Changing of state borders of the Azerbaijan Republic is the groung for referendum.

Question: Does the ratification of any international treaty trigger a referendum?
Comment: Milli Majlis of the Azerbaijan Republic ratifies and denunciates international treaties of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Question: Does the ratification of certain international treaties trigger a referendum?
Comment: Milli Majlis of the Azerbaijan Republic ratifies and denunciates international treaties of the Republic of Azerbaijan

Question: Does the association with any other state or international organisation trigger a referendum?
Comment: The President of the Azerbaijan Republic submits recommendations to Milli Majlis of the Azerbaijan Republic about establishment of diplomatic representations of the Azerbaijan Republic in foreign countries and under international organizations, appoints and dismisses diplomatic representatives of the Azerbaijan Republic in foreign countries and in international organizations.

Question: Does the association with certain states or international organisations trigger a referendum?
Comment: The President of the Azerbaijan Republic submits recommendations to Milli Majlis of the Azerbaijan Republic about establishment of diplomatic representations of the Azerbaijan Republic in foreign countries and under international organizations, appoints and dismisses diplomatic representatives of the Azerbaijan Republic in foreign countries and in international organizations.

Comment: In Bulgaria, the citizen-initiated agenda proposal creates an obligation for the state organ to debate the proposal and to announce its decision in a three-month period after the submission of the proposal. However, there is no obligation for the state body to take a particular decision.

Question: Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
Sources: Articles 44-53 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: What is the total number of signatures required?
Sources: Articles 45 and 47 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The law provides that an agenda initiative can be launched by at least 50 citizens. There is no legal requirement for the number of collected signatures. However, the more signtures are collected, the more pressure could be put on the authorities to adopt a certain decision.

Question: Is there a territorial threshold for signature gathering?
Comment: For the national agenda initiative there is no treshhold and the signatures are collected on the territory of the country.

Question: What is the time limit for collecting the required number of signatures (in days)?
Sources: Article 48(2) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Are there any restrictions on where the signatures can be collected?
Do signatories have to provide identification documents in addition to personal information when signing the initiative?
Sources: Article 49 (3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Citizens who are eligible to vote shall write down on the forms their full name, PIN, and permanent or current address and shall put their signature.

Question: Is it possible to gather signatures electronically?
Are the signatures systematically verified?
Sources: Article 51(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Who checks the signatures?
Sources: Article 51(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The signatures are verified by a special directortare at the Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works which maintains information about the population. The directorate verifies the information and sends back the results in a document.

Sources: Article 44 (1) of  the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The national agenda initiative is a citizens' proposal to Parliament or to the Executive on issues of national significance.

Who has to formally react to a successful agenda proposal?
Sources: Article 44 and 52 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: What form does that reaction have to take?
Sources: Article 52 of  the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance.
Comment: The relevant bodies (Parliament or the Executive) need to discuss the initiative and within a three-month announce their decision as well as the measures for the implementation of this decision on their respective websites, in one national daily newspaper and in the public electronic media.

Question: Does this type of instrument exist at the subnational level?
Sources: Article 46 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The agenda initiative can be used at the level of a municipality, region, community or town.

Question: Is the instrument available at national level?
Sources: Article 10(1)(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the Public Power and Local Self-Governance

Sources: Article 1(2) of the Constitution and Article 10(1)(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Under what conditions can the instrument be initiated (number of ministers, whole government, President etc.)?
Sources: Article 10(1)(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The law does not specify. In principle the decisions of the Council of Ministers are taken by a consensus of the ministers who are present at the meeting

Sources: Article 10(4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Is there a clarity of the question requirement?
Sources: Article 10(4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The proposal must contain one or several questions which require a "yes" or "no" answer. The questions shall be written in Bulgarian, shortly, precisely and clearly.

Question: Is there a unity of form requirement?
Is there a unity of substance requirement?
Are there any other formal limits? If Yes, describe in comments.
Are certain type of legal acts excluded from being the subject of it?
Sources: Article 9(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Referendums cannot be held on legal acts and codes which regulate a certain area in its entirety (for instance the Family Code).

Question: Are constitutional amendments excluded from being the subject of it?
Sources: Article 9(2)(1) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Constitutional amendments are allowed with the exception of constitutional amendments which fall within the prerogative of the extraordinary Parliament.

Question: Are the legal provisions challenged before or after their entry into force?
Comment: A national referendum in Bulgaria could be held on any issue which falls within the competence of Parliament. In this sense, certain legal provision could be challenged both before and after its entry into force. However, this issue is not specifically regulated in the law.

Question: Can only issues of special importance be the subject of referendums?
Sources: Article 9 (1) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: A national referendum shall be held for the purpose of direct citizen voting on issues of national importance

Question: Can only certain enumerated issues be the subject of referendums?
Are there any prohibited issues?
Sources: Article 9(2) and (3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance, Article 158 of the Constitution

Question: Are referendums on constitutional amendments prohibited?
Comment: Constitutional amendments are allowed with the exceptions of constitutional amendments which fall within the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament. (See in Article 158 of the Constitution)

Question: Are referendums related to international law obligations prohibited?
Are referendums related to fundamental rights and freedoms prohibited?
Comment: Fundamental rights can be the subject of a referendum, the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament is limited to the one provision about the restrictions on fundamental rights in general.

Question: Are referendums on state structure or form of government prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)1 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance , Article 158 of the Constitution
Comment: Issue falls within the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament

Question: Are referendums on state symbols prohibited?
Are referendums on the official language prohibited?
Are referendums on territorial issues or territorial integrity prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)1 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance , Article 158 of the Constitution
Comment: Issue falls within the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament

Question: Are referendums on state finances (budget, taxes, or other financial obligations) prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)3,4 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Are referendums on issues related to national security (military, police, secret services) prohibited?
Are referendums on emergency powers (declaration of war, state of emergency etc) or urgent matters prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)2 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Are referendums on pardon and amnesty prohibited?
Comment: Implicitly limited, because the competences are delegated to the President and the Parliament.

Question: Are referendums on naturalisation issues prohibited?
Comment: Implicitly limited, because the competences are delegated to the President.

Question: Are referendums on minorities or minority rights prohibited?
Are referendums on the rules of elections and referendums prohibited?
Are referendums on the election or appointment of state officials or civil service laws prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)2 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Are referendums on legislative competences prohibited?
Sources: Article 9(2)1,5 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Are referendums on executive competences prohibited?
Comment: There is no explicit prohibition, but it could touch upon the competences of the Extraordinary Parliament

Question: Are referendums on issues related to the judiciary (competences, independence etc) prohibited?
Comment: There is no explicit prohibition, but it could touch upon the competences of the Extraordinary Parliament

Question: Are referendums on issues related to local governance prohibited?
Comment: There is no explicit prohibition, but it could touch upon the competences of the Extraordinary Parliament

Question: Are there any other prohibited issues?
Sources: Article 9(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Laws which regulate as a whole a certain area (for instance the Criminal Code) cannot be subject to referendum in their entirety.

Question: Is it mandatory to call the referendum?
Is the referendum result binding?
Sources: Article 9(7), Article 23 of the 2009 Act on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The referendum result is binding only if a certain statutory majority of voters has been reached.

Question: Turnout quorum
Sources: Article 23(1) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: More than the number of voters who participated in the last parliamentary elections (if lower but above 20 %, then advisory)

Sources: Article 23(1) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Comment: The proposal for such a referendum at a local level could be made by the mayor (as the local authority with executive functions).

Comment: At the local level this referendum is initiated by a certain number of the members of the municipal council.

Question: Is the instrument available at national level?
Sources: Article 10(1)(5) and 10(2) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the Public Power and Local Self-Governance
Comment: There are two types of citizens' initiatives to hold a referendum. The first one is the right to initiate a referendum where a certain number of citizens (at least 200 000) submits a proposal to Parliament and the latter decides whether to hold a referendum. The second one is where a certain number of citizens (at least 400,000) submits a proposal for referendum and Parliament must hold a referendum.

Question: Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
Sources: Article 1(2) of the Constitution and Articles 9,10, 12-25 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: What is the total number of signatures required?
Sources: Article 10(1)(5) and Article 10(2) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: There are two types of citizens' initiatives to hold a referendum. The first one is the right to initiate a referendum where a certain number of citizens (at least 200 000) submits a proposal to Parliament and the latter decides whether to hold a referendum. The second one is where a certain number of citizens (at least 400,000) submits a proposal for referendum and Parliament must hold a referendum.

Question: Is there a territorial threshold for signature gathering?
What is the time limit for collecting the required number of signatures (in days)?
Sources: Article 12(8) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The time-limit is three months from the date on which Parliament was notified by the initiative committee that there has been a citizen initiative for referendum and a question has been formulated.

Question: Are there any restrictions on where the signatures can be collected?
Do signatories have to provide identification documents in addition to personal information when signing the initiative?
Sources: Article 12 (4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Citizens who want to support the proposal shall write the following on the form: 1. full name; 2. personal identification number (PIN)

Question: Is it possible to gather signatures electronically?
Are the signatures systematically verified?
Sources: Article 13(2) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: When the proposal is registered in the special register at Parliament, the Chair of Parliament sends the list of the signatories to the relevant directorate at the Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works which maintains the public registers of the population and verifies the signatures.

Question: Who checks the signatures?
Sources: Article 13(2) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: Special department at the Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works

Question: Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Comment: There is no remedy for the individual whose signature has been invalidated. However, if due to the invalidation the number of signatures falls under the statutory requirement, the Chair of Parliament gives one month to the initiative committee to collect the necessary signatures (section 13(4) of the 2009 Law).

Question: Is there a substantive admissibility check?
Sources: Article 13(2) and (4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The proposal is submitted for discussion by Parliament only if it corresponds to the formal statutory requirements.

Question: Who decides about the substantive admissibility?
Sources: Article 13(4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance.
Comment: In fact, it is the Chair of Parliament who conducts the check. In case of discrepancies, the proposal is sent back to the initiative committee which should correct the irregularities within one month.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on substantive admissibility?
Sources: Article 6 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Who decides about the claim for remedy in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Sources: Article 6 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Question: Who can initiate the substantive remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Sources: Article 6 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Is there an evidentiary procedure in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the substantive admissibility procedure binding?
Sources: Article 13(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The irregularities must be corrected, otherwise the proposal cannot be discussed by Parliament.

Question: Is invalidity the legal consequence of substantive inadmissibility?
Sources: Article 13(3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance.
Comment: If the initiative committee fails to correct the irregularities, the procedure is terminated and no discussions in Parliament are held.

Question: Does the proposal have to be submitted as a (draft) legal text?
Are there any formal limits on the wording of the referendum proposal?
Sources: Article 10(4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Sources: Article 10(4) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: The proposal must contain one or several questions which require a "yes" or "no" answer. The questions shall be written in Bulgarian, shortly, precisely and clearly.

Question: Is there a unity of form requirement?
Is there a unity of substance requirement?
Are there any other formal limits? If Yes, describe in comments.
Can only issues of special importance be the subject of referendums?
Sources: article 9 (1) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance
Comment: A national referendum shall be held for the purpose of direct citizen voting on issues of national importance

Question: Can only certain enumerated issues be the subject of referendums?
Are there any prohibited issues?
Sources: Article 9(2) and (3) of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance, Article 158 of the Constitution

Question: Are referendums on constitutional amendments prohibited?
Comment: Constitutional amendments are allowed with the exceptions of constitutional amendments which fall within the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament. (See in Article 158 of the Constitution)

Question: Are referendums related to international law obligations prohibited?
Are referendums related to fundamental rights and freedoms prohibited?
Comment: Fundamental rights can be the subject of a referendum, the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament is limited to the one provision about the restrictions on fundamental rights in general.

Question: Are referendums on state structure or form of government prohibited?
Are referendums on state symbols prohibited?
Are referendums on the official language prohibited?
Are referendums on territorial issues or territorial integrity prohibited?

Comment: Issue falls within the competence of the Extraordinary Parliament

Sources: Article 9(2)3,4 of the 2009 Law on the Direct Participation of Citizens in the State Power and the Local Self-Governance

Comment: Implicitly limited, because the competences are delegated to the President and the Parliament.

Comment: Implicitly limited, because the competences are delegated to the President.

Question: Are referendums on minorities or minority rights prohibited?

Comment: The Law on Referendum stipulates that the initiators shall deliver the signatures to the Parliament. Question: Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Is there a formal admissibility check?
Sources: Art 8g of the Law on Referendum and other type of citizen initiatives at state, regional and local level, Art 87 of the Constitutional Law on the Constitutional Court
Comment: The Parliament (after the signatures and the initiative have been formally presented to the Parliament) can ask the Constitutional Court to check, if the referendum question is in line with the Constitution and if the formal preconditions set in the Law on referendum are met. The formulation of the legal text does not indicate that the Parliament must address the Constitutional Court.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Sources: Art 8g of the Law on referendum, Art. 95 of the Constitutional Law on the Constitutional court
Comment: It is not a remedy per se: the Parliament (after the signatures and the initiative have been formally presented to the Parliament) can ask the Constitutional Court to check, if the referendum question is in line with the Constitution and if the formal preconditions set in the Law on referendum are met.

Question: Is formal admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Sources: Art. 95 of the Constitutional Law on the Constitutional court
Comment: The Constitutional court shall make a decision about admissibility within 30 days. In this procedure it can undertake certain actions to collect information.

Question: Do participants have a right to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure?
Is there an evidentiary procedure in the formal admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Sources: Art. 95 of the Constitutional Law on the Constitutional court
Comment: In case the Constitutional Court issues a decision that the initiative referendum question is not in line with the Constitution or is not acceptable for some other missing legal requirement, it would be binding and the Parliament would have to issue a decision of non-admissibility. In case the Constitutional Court issues opinions and public notices ex officio, they are not binding legally, but they have influenced the process every time they were used as a tool of communication by the Constitutional Court.

Comment: Based on Art. 87 (3) of the Constitution the Croatian Parliament shall call a referendum upon the issues from sections 1 and 2 of this Article when so demanded by ten percent of all voters in the Republic of Croatia. Section 1 states that the Croatian Parliament may call a referendum on a proposal for the amendment of the Constitution, on a bill, or any other issue within its competence.

Sources: Sections 1 and 2 of act of 26 December 2017, number 1672, cf. order of 17 January 2018, number 35 (on the establishment of a system for citizen-initiated agenda proposals to the Parliament).

Question: Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
Sources: Sections 1 and 2 of act of 26 December 2017, number 1672, cf. order of 17 January 2018, number 35 (on the establishment of a system for citizen-initiated agenda proposals to the Parliament).

Question: What is the total number of signatures required?
Sources: Section 15 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Is there a territorial threshold for signature gathering?
What is the time limit for collecting the required number of signatures (in days)?
Sources: Sections 12 and 15 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Sources: Section 2 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Do signatories have to provide identification documents in addition to personal information when signing the initiative?
Sources: Section 13 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Is it possible to gather signatures electronically?
Sources: Section 2 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Are the signatures systematically verified?
Sources: Section 13 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Who checks the signatures?
Sources: Order of 17 January 2018, number 35, The Parliament Administration is the authority responsible for the system. It reads the agenda proposal and is entitled to reject it from being published on www.borgerforslag.dk, if the proposal does not meet the general requirements. But the checking of the signatures is done automatically - when signing, the citizen has to type in its social security number and thus the system can check that the citizen is entitled to vote for Parliament elections (which is the only requirement for signing an agenda proposal).

Question: Is there a legal remedy against invalidation of signatures?
Is there a formal admissibility check?
Sources: Section 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Who decides about the formal admissibility?
Sources: Section 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35, The Parliament Administration

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Who decides about the claim for remedy in the formal admissibility procedure?
Who can initiate the formal remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Does the formal admissibility procedure take place before the signature collection?
Sources: Section 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Is formal admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Sources: Section 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35. The Parliament Administration is not subject to the procedural rules governing the general administration. Thus, the Parliament Administration just decides whether the requirements are met and inform the proposer and the co-proposers about its decision.

Question: Do participants have a right to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure?
Is there an evidentiary procedure in the formal admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Sources: Section 12.2, of order of 17 January 2018, number 35. If, after an agenda proposal has been published and is open for signatures, information surface which would have entailed a rejection of the proposal, the Parliament Administration can stop the proposal's collection of signatures and take it down form the website. If so, the proposer and the co-proposers are informed about the decision. But the proposer can propose the same agenda proposal again if its title is changed.

Sources: Section 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Does the proposal have to be submitted as a (draft) legal text?
Sources: Sections 5 and 11 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35. The initiative has to have an adequate title, an initiative text, and an explanatory and elaborating text (section 5). And it has to be formulated as a concrete proposal (section 11, paragraph 2, number 6).

Question: Are there any formal limits on the wording of the referendum proposal?
Sources: Section 5 of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Is there a clarity of the question requirement?
Sources: Section 11.2, number 4, of order of 17 January 2018, number 35. The initiative is rejected if it is completely incoherent or incomprehensible.

Question: Is there a unity of form requirement?
Sources: Section 11.2, number 6, of order of 17 January 2018, number 35

Question: Is there a unity of substance requirement?
Sources: Section 11.2, number 7, of order of 17 January 2018, number 35. The initiative is rejected if it contains several different proposals that have no clear substantive context among themselves.

Question: Who has to formally react to a successful agenda proposal?
Sources: According to the travaux préparatoires, it is expected that one of the members of the Parliament, which is part of one of the parties which have voted for this agenda initiative-system, will take up the agenda initiative and present it for the Parliament. Though, there is no legal obligation to do so.

Question: What form does that reaction have to take?
Sources: The Parliament member taking up the initiative presents it for the Parliament and then they discuss whether to put it into an actual Parliamentary motion.

Is the referendum result binding?
Sources: Sections 42 and 88 of the Constitution. If the result of the referendum is "no", then the bill cannot be affirmed by the Government and thus cannot be given force. If the result is “yes”, then the Government still has the power not to affirm the bill, and thus the referendum will not have changed anything (but in practice, it is hardly imaginable that the Government would decide not to affirm the bill in such a situation - especially because the Parliament can, at anytime, pass a vote of no confidence pursuant to section 15).

Question: Turnout quorum
Sources:
Sections 42.5, and 88 of the Constitution. For the negative referendums: No approval quorum. The only way the referendum can be rejected is if a majority of the votes are "no"-votes and that majority make up for at least 30 % of all the persons entitled to vote.
For the positive referendums: Simple majority (and that majority has to make up for at least 40 % of all the persons entitled to vote).

Question: Approval quorum
Sources:
Sections 42.5, and 88 of the Constitution. For the negative referendums: No approval quorum. The only way the referendum can be rejected is if a majority of the votes are "no"-votes and that majority make up for at least 30 % of all the persons entitled to vote.
For the positive referendums: Simple majority (and that majority has to make up for at least 40 % of all the persons entitled to vote).
Comment: Simple majority, if more than 30 or 40 % of all voters approve

Does the ratification of any international treaty trigger a referendum?
Does the ratification of certain international treaties trigger a referendum?
Does the association with any other state or international organisation trigger a referendum?
Does the association with certain states or international organisations trigger a referendum?
Are there any other issues or events that trigger a referendum?
Sources: Section 29.2 of the Constitution. If a simple majority in the Parliament agrees to change the age qualification for suffrage, a referendum is triggered

Question: Are there any exceptions when a referendum is not required to take place even though the triggering event or issue exists?
Are there any procedures for reviewing the triggering issue or event?
Are there any unamendable constitutional provisions that limit referendums?
Does this type of instrument exist at the subnational level?
Is the instrument available at national level?
Sources: Section 42 of the Constitution, A "binding" referendum can only be held in Denmark, if there is legal basis for the referendum in the Constitution.  It is possible to hold a "non-binding" referendum - even without legal basis for it in the Constitution - and there are no limits as to what issues such a non-binding referendum can concern, as long as there is basis for the referendum in a regular law (a bill passed by the Parliament only becomes law if it is affirmed by the Government (section 22 of the constitution)).

Question: Is there an explicit legal basis for this type of referendum?
Under what conditions can the instrument be initiated (number of ministers, whole government, President etc.)?
Sources: Section 42.1 of the Constitution. One-third of the Parliament, ie. at least 60 members, has to request the referendum within three week-days from the passing of the bill.

Question: Is there a formal admissibility check?
Who decides about the formal admissibility?
Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Who decides about the claim for remedy in the formal admissibility procedure?
Who can initiate the formal remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Is formal admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Do participants have a right to be heard in the formal admissibility procedure?
Is there an evidentiary procedure in the formal admissibility procedure?
Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Is invalidity the legal consequence of formal inadmissibility?
Is there a substantive admissibility check?
Sources: Section 42, paragraph 6, of the Danish Constitution

Question: Who decides about the substantive admissibility?
Sources: Section 42, paragraph 4, of the Danish Constitution. The Prime Minister can choose either to call the referendum or to affirm the bill (section 22) and thus disregard the request for a referendum.

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on substantive admissibility?
Sources: Section 3 of the Danish Constitution. But not a legal remedy in the strict sense: If the Prime Minister decides to affirm the bill (and thus not to call the referendum), it is possible to go to the courts. But this does not change the fact that the affirmed bill is now law. If the courts find that the Prime Minister should have called the referendum, then the law is invalid. The courts cannot order the Prime Minister (or the Parliament) to call the referendum.

Question: Who decides about the claim for remedy in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Who can initiate the substantive remedy procedure (state actor - initiator - anyone)?
Sources: In principle, everyone who has a legal interest (sufficient interest) can initiate the "remedy" procedure.

Question: Is substantive admissibility decided in a special procedure?
Sources: There are no procedural rules as to how the Prime Minister decides.  In the "remedy" procedure, all the usual procedural rules in the administration of justice apply.

Question: Do participants have a right to be heard in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Sources: There are no procedural rules as to how the Prime Minister decides.  In the "remedy" procedure, all the usual procedural rules in the administration of justice apply: so here, both plaintiff (e.g. the initiator) and the defendant (the state) have the right to be heard.

Question: Is there an evidentiary procedure in the substantive admissibility procedure?
Sources: There are no procedural rules as to how the Prime Minister decides.  In the "remedy" procedure, all the usual procedural rules in the administration of justice apply: so here, there is an evidentiary procedure.

Question: Are the legal consequences of the substantive admissibility procedure binding?
Sources: The courts cannot order the Prime Minister (or the Parliament) to call the referendum. The courts can only invalidate, i.e. invalidate those rules that should have been subject to a referendum.

Question: Is invalidity the legal consequence of substantive inadmissibility?
Sources: The Prime Minister cannot unilaterally rewrite the topic etc. of the referendum - he/she can only decide to call the referendum or not. The courts cannot order the Prime Minister (or the Parliament) to call the referendum. The courts can only invalidate, i.e. invalidate those rules that should have been subject to a referendum.

Question: Does the proposal have to be submitted as a (draft) legal text?
Sources: Section 42 of the Constitution, A prerequisite is a passed bill - and it is this passed bill that can be subject to a referendum.

If the result is “yes”, then the Government still has the power not to affirm the bill, and thus the referendum will not have changed anything (but in practice, it is hardly imaginable that the Government would decide not to affirm the bill in such a situation - especially because the Parliament can, at anytime, pass a vote of no confidence pursuant to section 15).

Question: Turnout quorum
Sources: Section 42, paragraph 5, of the Danish Constitution. For the bill to be rejected, a majority of the electors taking part in the voting, however, not less than 30 % of all persons entitled to vote, shall have voted against the Bill.

Sources: Section 42. 5, of the Constitution. For the bill to be rejected, a majority of the electors taking part in the voting, however, not less than 30 % of all persons entitled to vote, shall have voted against the Bill.

Comment: The authority to initiate a referendum in order to pass a bill or take a decision on another national policy matter is vested in the following persons or bodies: 1) members of the Riigikogu; 2) factions of the Riigikogu; 3) committees of the Riigikogu.

Question: Is there a formal admissibility check?

Question: Who decides about the formal admissibility?
Sources: Art. 129, Riigikogu Rules of Procedure and Internal Rules Act; Art. 91, 92, 93, Riigikogu Rules of Procedure and Internal Rules Act

Question: Is there a legal remedy against the decision on formal admissibility?
Sources: Article 18, Chancellor of Justice Act, Article 6,15 of the Constitutional Review Court Procedure Act
Comment: The Chancellor of Justice has a right to make a proposal to the Supreme Court to repeal the resolution of the Riigikogu concerning the submission of a draft Act or other national issue to a referendum, if he finds that a draft Act, except a draft Act to amend the Constitution, or other national issue which is submitted to a referendum is in conflict with the Constitution or that the Riigikogu has significantly violated the established procedure upon passage of the resolution to hold the referendum (Article 18, Chancellor of Justice Act). There was no examples of doing it towards parliamentary acts.

Sources: Article 49-54 of the Constitutional Review Court Procedure Act
Comment: Only in the Supreme Court procedure

Sources: Article 49-54 of the Constitutional Review Court Procedure Act
Comment: Only in the Supreme Court procedure

Question: Are the legal consequences of the formal admissibility procedures binding?
Sources: Art. 92 (3), Riigikogu Rules of Procedure and Internal Rules Act
Comment: If the Board of the Riigikogu finds that the bill or draft resolution does not comply with the requirements set out in section 92 of this Act, the Board returns that bill or draft resolution to the body or person who introduced or submitted it without designating a lead committee.

Sources: Article 46 of the Ordinance n ° 58-1067 of November 7, 1958 relating to the organic law on the Constitutional Council
Comment: The Constitutional Council is consulted by the Government on the organization of referendum operations. He is immediately informed of any action taken in this regard. In its case-law, the Constitutional Council recognized the possibility of controlling the Government decree on the organization of the referendum. See: Decision n° 2000-21 REF -july 25,  2000 Decision n° 2005-31 REF du march 24, 2005. The Constitutional Council also recognized a requirement of loyalty and clarity of the question asked in its decision n ° 87-226 DC of June 2, 1987

Question: Are there any prohibited issues?
Sources: Article 89 of the Constitution, Article 11 of the Constitution
Comment: Based on Article 89 of the Constitution, the republican form of government shall not be the object of any amendment. Article 11 does not prohibit any topics, however, by restricting referendums to "any Government Bill which deals with the organization of the public authorities, or with reforms relating to the economic or social policy of the Nation, and to the public services contributing thereto, or which provides for authorization to ratify a treaty which, although not contrary to the Constitution, would affect the functioning of the institutions", it excludes all issues not listed here.

Question: Are there any other issues or events that trigger a referendum?
Are there any exceptions when a referendum is not required to take place even though the triggering event or issue exists?
Sources: Article 88-5 and Article 89 of the Constitution
Comment: It is possible to override the obligation of the referendum by the Parliament: Article 89 of the Constitution : "However, a Government Bill to amend the Constitution shall not be submitted to referendum where the President of the Republic decides to submit it to Parliament convened in Congress; the Government Bill to amend the Constitution shall then be approved only if it is passed by a three-fifths majority of the votes cast. The Bureau of the Congress shall be that of the National Assembly". Article 88-5(1) of the Constitution : "Notwithstanding the foregoing, by passing a motion adopted in identical terms in each House by a three-fifths majority, Parliament may authorize the passing of the Bill according to the procedure provided for in paragraph three of article 89".

Question: Are there any procedures for reviewing the triggering issue or event?

Comment: No amendment procedure shall be commenced or continued where the integrity of national territory is placed in jeopardy. The republican form of government shall not be the object of any amendment.

Question: Does this type of instrument exist at the subnational level?
Comment: No ceding, exchanging or acquiring of territory shall be valid without the consent of the population concerned.

Question: Is the instrument available at national level?
Comment: Two different types of legislature-initiated referendums exist under Article 11: Based on Section 1 the "President of the Republic may, on a recommendation from the Government when Parliament is in session, or on a joint motion of the two Houses, published in the Journal Officiel, submit to a referendum any Government Bill which deals with the organization of the public authorities, or with reforms relating to the economic or social policy of the Nation, and to the public services contributing thereto, or which provides for authorization to ratify a treaty which, although not contrary to the Constitution, would affect the functioning of the institutions". The shared initiative is regulated under Section 3: "A referendum concerning a subject mentioned in the first paragraph may be held upon the initiative of one fifth of the Members of Parliament, supported by one tenth of the voters enrolled on the electoral register".

Comment: Article 11 (1) requires a majority, while (3) a minority

Comment: The Constitutional Council is consulted by the Government on the organization of referendum operations. He is immediately informed of any action taken in this regard. In its case-law, the Constitutional Council recognized the possibility of controlling the Government decree on the organization of the referendum. See: Decision n° 2000-21 REF -july 25,  2000 Decision n° 2005-31 REF du march 24, 2005. The Constitutional Council also recognized a requirement of loyalty and clarity of the question asked in its decision n ° 87-226 DC of June 2, 1987

Comment: The Constitutional Council is consulted by the Government on the organization of referendum operations. He is immediately informed of any action taken in this regard. The Constitutional Council also recognized a requirement of loyalty and clarity of the question asked in its decision n ° 87-226 DC of June 2, 1987

Comment: There is no claim for remedy in the formal admissibility procedure, because the decision of the Constitutional Council is a consultative advice.

Comment: Any Government Bill which deals with the organization of the public authorities, or with reforms relating to the economic or social policy of the Nation, and to the public services contributing thereto, or which provides for authorization to ratify a treaty which, although not contrary to the Constitution, would affect the functioning of the institutions.

Question: Are there any prohibited issues?
Sources: Article 89 of the Constitution, Article 11 of the Constitution
Comment: Based on Article 89 of the Constitution, the republican form of government shall not be the object of any amendment. Article 11 does not prohibit any topics, however, by restricting referendums to "any Government Bill which deals with the organization of the public authorities, or with reforms relating to the economic or social policy of the Nation, and to the public services contributing thereto, or which provides for authorization to ratify a treaty which, although not contrary to the Constitution, would affect the functioning of the institutions", it excludes all issues not listed here.

Comment: The decision taken as a result of the referendum shall be enforced from the date of its publication; it shall have a legal force and is final. Legislative and executive authorities of Georgia are obliged to harmonize Georgian legislation and other legal acts with the referendum results within one month.

Comment: The decision taken as a result of the referendum shall be enforced from the date of its publication; it shall have a legal force and is final. The results of a referendum have a direct effect.  Legislative and executive authorities of Georgia are obliged to harmonize Georgian legislation and other legal acts with the referendum results within one month.

Comment: No special rules apply, but the proactive rules can be used to abrogate legal acts. Most recently the 15/2017. (VI. 30.) CC decision clarified that the Fundamental Law does not limit the aim or form of the referendum initiative. It can be aimed to amend, abrogate or create a legislative act or other legislative decision; the question can be the summary of its content, an actual legislative provision or a reference to a legal act or proposed legal act.
